      Modeling electrochromic poly-dioxythiophene-containing materials through TDDFT
      Wheeler, D. L.; Rainwater, L. E.; Green, A. R.; Tomlinson, A. L.
      Physical Chemistry Chemical Physics (2017), 19 (30), 20251-20258CODEN: PPCPFQ; ISSN:1463-9076. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
      A DFT/TDDFT model was developed to predict the chem. properties for three colored to nearly transmissive electrochromic polymers synthesized by the John Reynolds's group. Using a functional-basis set pairing of mPW1PBE/cc-PVDZ along with the conductor polarizable calcn. model (CPCM), simulated neutral spectra showed a strong correlation to the exptl. UV-Vis data where the largest abs. peak max. difference was 14 nm. Frontier MOs, electronic transitions, and ground-state geometries of these systems were evaluated to provide further information about the oxidative process the polymers undergo. Here we report the first colorimetric model using this level of theory.

PProDOT-Me2 ad PProDOT-Me exhibit much higher contrast and more rapid switching times than the parent PProDOT.

      Direct (Hetero)arylation Polymerization: An Effective Route to 3,4-Propylenedioxythiophene-Based Polymers with Low Residual Metal Content
      Estrada, Leandro A.; Deininger, James J.; Kamenov, George D.; Reynolds, John R.
      ACS Macro Letters (2013), 2 (10), 869-873CODEN: AMLCCD; ISSN:2161-1653. (American Chemical Society)
      We report the use of direct (hetero)-arylation polymns. (DHAP) as a means of obtaining 3,4-propylenedioxythiophene-based conjugated polymers for use in electrochromics. This method offers a rapid route to achieving polymers in high yields with simplified purifn. procedures and low residual metal content, as detd. by inductive coupled plasma-mass spectrometry (ICP-MS). The studied polymers possess comparable electrochromic properties to those previously reported by our group, implying that their switching ability from a colored to a transmissive state is independent of the residual metallic impurities.

      Pouliot, J.-R.; Grenier, F.; Blaskovits, J. T.; Beaupré, S.; Leclerc, M. Direct (Hetero)arylation Polymerization: Simplicity for Conjugated Polymer Synthesis. Chem. Rev. 2016, 116, 14225– 14274,  DOI: 10.1021/acs.chemrev.6b00498
      [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
      73
      Direct (Hetero)arylation Polymerization: Simplicity for Conjugated Polymer Synthesis
      Pouliot, Jean-Remi; Grenier, Francois; Blaskovits, J. Terence; Beaupre, Serge; Leclerc, Mario
      Chemical Reviews (Washington, DC, United States) (2016), 116 (22), 14225-14274CODEN: CHREAY; ISSN:0009-2665. (American Chemical Society)
      A review. Direct (hetero)arylation polymn. (DHAP) has recently been established as an environmentally benign method for the prepn. of conjugated polymers. This synthetic tool features the formation of C-C bonds between halogenated (hetero)arenes and simple (hetero)arenes with active C-H bonds, thereby circumventing the prepn. of organometallic derivs. and decreasing the overall prodn. cost of conjugated polymers. Since its inception, selectivity and reactivity of DHAP procedures were improved tremendously through the careful scrutiny of polymn. outcomes and the fine-tuning of reaction conditions. A broad range of monomers, from simple arenes to complex functionalized heteroarenes, can now be readily polymd. The successful application of DHAP led to nearly defect-free conjugated polymers possessing comparable, if not slightly better, characteristics than their counterparts prepd. using more classical cross-coupling methods. This comprehensive review describes the mechanisms involved in this process, from exptl. and theor. standpoints, and presents an up-to-date compendium of materials obtained by this mean and exposes its current limitations and challenges.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC28XhslOmu7nI&md5=a77872e56483484e07eb6030052bd598

      Gobalasingham, N. S.; Thompson, B. C. Direct Arylation Polymerization: A Guide to Optimal Conditions for Effective Conjugated Polymers. Prog. Polym. Sci. 2018, 83, 135– 201,  DOI: 10.1016/j.progpolymsci.2018.06.002
      [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
      74
      Direct arylation polymerization: A guide to optimal conditions for effective conjugated polymers
      Gobalasingham, Nemal S.; Thompson, Barry C.
      Progress in Polymer Science (2018), 83 (), 135-201CODEN: PRPSB8; ISSN:0079-6700. (Elsevier Ltd.)
      The rapid increase in the breadth and scope of transformations that involve metal-promoted activation of C-H bonds is fundamentally changing the field of synthetic chem. Direct arylation polymn. is a newly established synthetic protocol for atom economical, effective, and affordable prepn. of conjugated polymers, which continue to be incredibly advantageous as operative materials for a diverse and continually evolving array of applications. This route toward conjugated polymers for high performance materials is particularly appealing because it circumvents the prepn. of organometallic derivs. and the assocd. cryogenic air- and water-free reactions. Although a broad range of monomers are now readily polymerizable, direct arylation polymn. is known to produce defects in the chem. structure, which have a strong impact on the optical, electronic, and thermal properties of conjugated polymers. Fundamental understanding of the underlying considerations when employing different reaction protocols is required to truly enable a broad reaching platform.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC1cXht1SjsbrI&md5=28ce29289b5cd6e7ef6b1ca3c342cddb

      Collier, G. S.; Reynolds, J. R. Exploring the Utility of Buchwald Ligands for C–H Oxidative Direct Arylation Polymerizations. ACS Macro Lett. 2019, 8, 931– 936,  DOI: 10.1021/acsmacrolett.9b00395
      [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
      75
      Exploring the Utility of Buchwald Ligands for C-H Oxidative Direct Arylation Polymerizations
      Collier, Graham S.; Reynolds, John R.
      ACS Macro Letters (2019), 8 (8), 931-936CODEN: AMLCCD; ISSN:2161-1653. (American Chemical Society)
      Oxidative C-H/C-H cross-coupling polymns. provide an opportunity to synthesize conjugated polymers with an increased ease of monomer prepn., reduced environmental impact, and increased sustainability. Considering these attributes, it is necessary to expand the diversity of monomers that readily and efficiently participate in this coupling strategy to enable the development of conjugated polymers with a wide range of properties. Herein, the oxidative direct arylation polymn. toolbox is expanded to include 3,4-propylenedioxythiophene being synthesized via C-H/C-H cross-coupling methodologies. In conjunction with these efforts, the utilization of Buchwald ligands in C-H/C-H cross coupling polymns. also is reported, and variations in the ligand structure provide insight into the role ligand choice has on C-H cross-coupling polymns. Specifically, it is detd. that the phosphine functionality affects the rate-detg., concerted metalation-deprotonation step of the catalytic cycle, while bulky iso-Pr substituents on the ligand's lower aryl ring promote reductive elimination. By balancing these steric effects on the ancillary ligands, polymers are synthesized to exhibit mol. wts. above the effective conjugation length, with recovered yields >90%. In addn. to expanding the scope of conjugated polymers accessible via oxidative direct arylation polymn., these results provide the foundational understanding for utilizing Buchwald-type ligands in C-H-activated polymns.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC1MXhtlOju7zJ&md5=d89af15f41c7206f6204ee6f311485b3

      Lo, C. K.; Gautam, B. R.; Selter, P.; Zheng, Z.; Oosterhout, S. D.; Constantinou, I.; Knitsch, R.; Wolfe, R. M. W.; Yi, X.; Brédas, J.-L.; So, F.; Toney, M. F.; Coropceanu, V.; Hansen, M. R.; Gundogdu, K.; Reynolds, J. R. Every Atom Counts: Elucidating the Fundamental Impact of Structural Change in Conjugated Polymers for Organic Photovoltaics. Chem.       [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
      76
      Every Atom Counts: Elucidating the Fundamental Impact of Structural Change in Conjugated Polymers for Organic Photovoltaics
      Lo, Chi Kin; Gautam, Bhoj R.; Selter, Philipp; Zheng, Zilong; Oosterhout, Stefan D.; Constantinou, Iordania; Knitsch, Robert; Wolfe, Rylan M. W.; Yi, Xueping; Bredas, Jean-Luc; So, Franky; Toney, Michael F.; Coropceanu, Veaceslav; Hansen, Michael Ryan; Gundogdu, Kenan; Reynolds, John R.
      Chemistry of Materials (2018), 30 (9), 2995-3009CODEN: CMATEX; ISSN:0897-4756. (American Chemical Society)
      As many conjugated polymer-based org. photovoltaic (OPV) materials provide substantial solar power conversion efficiencies (as high as 13%), it is important to develop a deeper understanding of how the primary repeat unit structures impact device performance. We have varied the group 14 atom (C, Si, Ge) at the center of a bithiophene fused ring to elucidate the impact of a minimal repeat unit structure change on the optical, transport, and morphol. properties, which ultimately control device performance. Careful polymn. and polymer purifn. produced 3 1-atom change donor-acceptor conjugated alternating copolymers with similar mol. wts. and dispersities. DFT calcn., absorption spectroscopy, and high-temp. soln. 1H NMR results indicate that poly(dithienosilole-alt-thienopyrrolodione), P(DTS-TPD), and poly(dithienogermole-alt-thienopyrrolodione), P(DTG-TPD) exhibit different rotational conformations when compared to poly(cyclopentadithiophene-alt-thienopyrrolodione), P(DTC-TPD). Solid-state 1H MASNMR expts. reveal that the greater probability of the anticonformation in P(DTS-TPD) and P(DTG-TPD) prevail in the solid phase. The conformational variation seen in soln. and solid-state NMR in turn affects the polymer stacking and intermol. interaction. Two-dimension 1H-1H DQ-SQ NMR correlation spectra shows arom.-arom. correlations for P(DTS-TPD) and P(DTG-TPD), which however, is absent for P(DTC-TPD). In a thin-film interchain packing study using grazing incidence wide-angle x-ray scattering (GIWAXS), we observe the π-face of the conjugated backbones of P(DTC-TPD) aligned edge-on to the substrate, whereas in contrast the π-faces of P(DTS-TPD) and P(DTG-TPD) align parallel to the surface. These differences in polymer conformations and backbone orientations lead to variations in the OPV performance of blends with the fullerene PC71BM, with the device contg. P(DTC-TPD):PCBM having a lower fill factor and a lower power conversion efficiency. Ultrafast transient absorption spectroscopy shows the P(DTC-TPD):PCBM blend to have a more pronounced triplet formation from bimol. recombination of initially sepd. charges. With a combination of sub-bandgap external quantum efficiency measurements and DFT calcns., we present evidence that the greater charge recombination loss is the result of a lower lying triplet energy level for P(DTC-TPD), leading to a higher rate of recombination and lower OPV device performance. Importantly, this study ties ultimate photovoltaic performance to morphol. features in the active films that are induced from the processing soln. and are a result of minimal 1-atom differences in polymer repeat unit structure.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC1cXnvVWju7o%253D&md5=49b0e216f25a98f9f57125163dd565ce

      Kaake, L.; Dang, X.-D.; Leong, W. L.; Zhang, Y.; Heeger, A.; Nguyen, T.-Q. Effects of Impurities on Operational Mechanism of Organic Bulk Heterojunction Solar Cells. Adv. Mater. 2013, 25, 1706– 1712,  DOI: 10.1002/adma.201203786
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      77
      Effects of Impurities on Operational Mechanism of Organic Bulk Heterojunction Solar Cells
      Kaake, Loren; Dang, Xuan-Dung; Leong, Wei Lin; Zhang, Yuan; Heeger, Alan; Nguyen, Thuc-Quyen
      Advanced Materials (Weinheim, Germany) (2013), 25 (12), 1706-1712CODEN: ADVMEW; ISSN:0935-9648. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
      The effect is investigated of 14,14,8,8-teracyanoquinodimethane (TCNQ) and [6,6]phenyl-C84-butyric acid Me ester (PC84BM) on the performance of PCDTBT:PC60BM devices to gain insight into whether differing impurity shapes may lead to different loss mechanisms. Light intensity dependent solar cell characteristics, photoconductive at. force microscopy, charge carrier mobility using single-carrier diodes, and transient absorption spectroscopy were performed to probe the loss mechanism. Although solar cell performance is decreased upon the addn. of TCNQ, a qual. different loss mechanism is found for TCNQ and PC84BM.

      Diemer, P. J.; Hayes, J.; Welchman, E.; Hallani, R.; Pookpanratana, S. J.; Hacker, C. A.; Richter, C. A.; Anthony, J. E.; Thonhauser, T.; Jurchescu, O. D.       Curtin, I. J.; Blaylock, D. W.; Holmes, R. J. Role of Impurities in Determining the Exciton Diffusion Length in Organic Semiconductors. Appl. Phys. Lett. 2016, 108, 163301,  DOI: 10.1063/1.4945688
      [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
      79
      Role of impurities in determining the exciton diffusion length in organic semiconductors
      Curtin, Ian J.; Blaylock, D. Wayne; Holmes, Russell J.
      Applied Physics Letters (2016), 108 (16), 163301/1-163301/4CODEN: APPLAB; ISSN:0003-6951. (American Institute of Physics)
      The design and performance of org. photovoltaic cells is dictated, in part, by the magnitude of the exciton diffusion length (LD). Despite the importance of this parameter, there have been few investigations connecting LD and materials purity. Here, we investigate LD for the org. small mol. N,N'-bis(naphthalen-1-yl)-N,N'-bis(phenyl)-benzidine as native impurities are systematically removed from the material. Thin films deposited from the as-synthesized material yield a value for LD, as measured by photoluminescence quenching, of (3.9 ± 0.5) nm with a corresponding photoluminescence efficiency (ηPL) of (25 ± 1)% and thin film purity of (97.1 ± 1.2)%, measured by high performance liq. chromatog. After purifn. by thermal gradient sublimation, the value of LD is increased to (4.7 ± 0.5) nm with a corresponding ηPL of (33 ± 1)% and purity of (98.3 ± 0.8)%. Interestingly, a similar behavior is also obsd. as a function of the deposition boat temp. Films deposited from the purified material at a high temp. give LD = (5.3 ± 0.8) nm with ηPL = (37 ± 1)% for films with a purity of (99.0 ± 0.3)% purity. Using a model of diffusion by Forster energy transfer, the variation of LD with purity is predicted as a function of ηPL and is in good agreement with measurements. The removal of impurities acts to decrease the non-radiative exciton decay rate and increase the radiative decay rate, leading to increases in both the diffusivity and exciton lifetime. The results of this work highlight the role of impurities in detg. LD, while also providing insight into the degree of materials purifn. necessary to achieve optimized exciton transport. (c) 2016 American Institute of Physics.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC28Xmt1elsLk%253D&md5=45e171601e62affd7be3e28e640baacc
    80. 80
      Bracher, C.; Yi, H.; Scarratt, N. W.; Masters, R.; Pearson, A. J.; Rodenburg, C.; Iraqi, A.; Lidzey, D. G. The Effect of Residual Palladium Catalyst on the Performance and Stability of PCDTBT:PC70BM Organic Solar Cells. Org. Electron. 2015, 27, 266– 273,  DOI: 10.1016/j.orgel.2015.10.001
      [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
      80
      The effect of residual palladium catalyst on the performance and stability of PCDTBT:PC70BM organic solar cells
      Bracher, Christopher; Yi, Hunan; Scarratt, Nicholas W.; Masters, Robert; Pearson, Andrew J.; Rodenburg, Cornelia; Iraqi, Ahmed; Lidzey, David G.
      Organic Electronics (2015), 27 (), 266-273CODEN: OERLAU; ISSN:1566-1199. (Elsevier B.V.)
      Palladium (Pd) is commonly used as a catalyst in the polymn. of conjugated polymers such as poly[N-9'-heptadecanyl-2,7-carbozole-alt-5,5-(4',7'-di-2-thenyl-2',1',3'-benzothiadiazole)] (PCDTBT). Here we explore the effect of residual catalyst on the performance of org. photovoltaic devices (OPVs) based on a PCDTBT:fullerene thin-film blend. We find that as the relative concn. of Pd increases, the power conversion efficiency of the PV is reduced, dropping from 4.55% to 2.42% as the Pd concn. was increased to 2570 ppm (relative to that of the PCDTBT). This redn. in efficiency resulted primarily from a redn. in PV fill factor and shunt-resistance, indicating the presence of current-shunts within the device. Using optical microscopy, laser beam induced current mapping and SEM, we are able to demonstrate that such current shunts are assocd. with micron-sized aggregates of Pd-contg. nanoparticles. We show that the presence of high concns. of Pd within a PCDTBT OPV contribute to a larger drop in efficiency during the initial 'burn-in' period.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2MXhs1Kru73O&md5=365f742c45851744ec56cd14e5f72eb7

      Usluer, Ö.; Abbas, M.; Wantz, G.; Vignau, L.; Hirsch, L.; Grana, E.; Brochon, C.; Cloutet, E.; Hadziioannou, G. Metal Residues in Semiconducting Polymers: Impact on the Performance of Organic Electronic Devices. ACS Macro Lett. 2014, 3, 1134– 1138,  DOI: 10.1021/mz500590d
      [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
      81
      Metal Residues in Semiconducting Polymers: Impact on the Performance of Organic Electronic Devices
      Usluer, Ozlem; Abbas, Mamatimin; Wantz, Guillaume; Vignau, Laurence; Hirsch, Lionel; Grana, Eftychia; Brochon, Cyril; Cloutet, Eric; Hadziioannou, Georges
      ACS Macro Letters (2014), 3 (11), 1134-1138CODEN: AMLCCD; ISSN:2161-1653. (American Chemical Society)
      The effect of impurities on the optoelectronic and charge transport properties of semiconducting polymers was studied through the performance of org. photovoltaics (OPVs) and org. field effect transistors (OFETs), resp. A model representative semiconducting polymer, i.e., poly(3-hexylthiophene) (P3HT), was synthesized and purified using different methods such as pptn., metals' complexation, and Soxhlet extn. After the purifn. processes, each fraction was analyzed to det. its compn. in metals (impurities) by various techniques. OFETs and OPVs fabricated from these purified polymer fractions show different charge carrier properties and photovoltaic behaviors. The purest fraction which was obtained after Soxhlet extn. complemented by metals' complexation with the help of ethylenediamine and 15-crown-5 ether showed the best performance in both OPVs and OFETs.

      Koch, F. P. V.; Rivnay, J.; Foster, S.; Müller, C.; Downing, J. M.; Buchaca-Domingo, E.; Westacott, P.; Yu, L.; Yuan, M.; Baklar, M.; Fei, Z.; Luscombe, C.; McLachlan, M. A.; Heeney, M.; Rumbles, G.; Silva, C.; Salleo, A.; Nelson, J.; Smith, P.; Stingelin, N. The Impact of Molecular Weight on Microstructure and Charge Transport in Semicrystalline Polymer Semiconductors–Poly(3-hexylthiophene), A Model Study. Prog. Polym. Sci. 2013, 38, 1978– 1989,  DOI: 10.1016/j.progpolymsci.2013.07.009

      82
      The impact of molecular weight on microstructure and charge transport in semicrystalline polymer semiconductors - poly(3-hexylthiophene), a model study
      Koch, Felix Peter Vinzenz; Rivnay, Jonathan; Foster, Sam; Muller, Christian; Downing, Jonathan M.; Buchaca-Domingo, Ester; Westacott, Paul; Yu, Liyang; Yuan, Mingjian; Baklar, Mohammed; Fei, Zhuping; Luscombe, Christine; McLachlan, Martyn A.; Heeney, Martin; Rumbles, Garry; Silva, Carlos; Salleo, Alberto; Nelson, Jenny; Smith, Paul; Stingelin, Natalie
      Progress in Polymer Science (2013), 38 (12), 1978-1989CODEN: PRPSB8; ISSN:0079-6700. (Elsevier Ltd.)
      A review. Electronic properties of org. semiconductors are often critically dependent upon their ability to order from the mol. level to the macro-scale, as is true for many other materials attributes of macromol. matter such as mech. characteristics. Therefore, understanding of the mol. assembly process and the resulting solid-state short- and long-range order is crit. to further advance the field of org. electronics. Here, we will discuss the structure development as a function of mol. wt. in thin films of a model conjugated polymer, poly(3-hexylthiophene) (P3HT), when processed from soln. and the melt. While focus is on the microstructural manipulation and characterization, we also treat the influence of mol. arrangement and order on electronic processes such as charge transport and show, based on classical polymer science arguments, how accounting for the structural complexity of polymers can provide a basis for establishing relevant processing/structure/property-interrelationships to explain some of their electronic features. Such relationships can assist with the design of new materials and definition of processing protocols that account for the mol. length, chain rigidity and propensity to order of a given system.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC3sXhtlaht7nN&md5=e618151d76d8b186b1d6bfe4a3633baf

      Electrochemistry of Conducting Polymers-Persistent Models and New Concepts
      Heinze, Jurgen; Frontana-Uribe, Bernardo A.; Ludwigs, Sabine
      Chemical Reviews (Washington, DC, United States) (2010), 110 (8), 4724-4771CODEN: CHREAY; ISSN:0009-2665. (American Chemical Society)
      A review. The scope of this review is mainly limited to novel electrochem. findings in the field of conducting polymers (CPs) involving the formation with mechanistic and electrosynthetic aspects, the charge storage mechanism, and related details. Basic properties and processes of CPs are discussed in light of recent results. An overview of recent electropolymn. methods, including the prepn. of nanostructures and new architectures as well as new strategies for tuning their properties are be given.

      Doping in solution as an order-inducing tool prior to film formation of regio-irregular polyalkylthiophenes
      Apperloo, Joke J.; Janssen, Rene A. J.; Nielsen, Martin M.; Bechgaard, Klaus
      Advanced Materials (Weinheim, Germany) (2000), 12 (21), 1594-1597CODEN: ADVMEW; ISSN:0935-9648. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH)
      Aligned poly(3-alkylthiophene) films are deposited by oxidn. doping in soln. prior to deposition. Thus, regio-irregular poly(3-octylthiophene) was doped using thianthrenium perchlorate in dichloromethane. The absorption spectra, UV spectra, and IR spectra were detd. Similar effects are obsd. for oxidized poly(3-hexylthiophene). X-ray diffraction was used to study spin cast films of poly(3-hexylthiophene) after oxidn. and oxidized films reduced with hydrazine. The structural order is discussed. FETs were prepd. from oxidized poly(3-hexylthiophene) with carrier mobilities of (1-3) × 10-4 cm2V-1s-1. The redn. can be used to create different types of order.

      Heimel, G. The Optical Signature of Charges in Conjugated Polymers. ACS Cent. Sci. 2016, 2, 309– 315,  DOI: 10.1021/acscentsci.6b00073
      [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
      85
      The Optical Signature of Charges in Conjugated Polymers
      Heimel, Georg
      ACS Central Science (2016), 2 (5), 309-315CODEN: ACSCII; ISSN:2374-7951. (American Chemical Society)
      Elec. charge flowing through org. semiconductors drives many of today's mobile phone displays and television screens, suggesting an internally consistent model of charge-carrier properties in these materials to have manifested. In conjugated polymers, charges give rise to addnl. absorption of light at wavelengths longer than those absorbed by the elec. neutral species. These characteristic absorption bands are universally being related to the emergence of localized energy levels shifted into the forbidden gap of org. semiconductors due to local relaxation of the mol. geometry. The traditional view on these energy levels and their occupation is incompatible with expected changes in electron removal and addn. energies upon charging mols. Local Coulomb repulsion, as captured by nonempirically optimized electronic-structure calcns., restores compatibility and suggests a different origin of the charge-induced optical transitions. These results challenge a widely accepted and long-established picture, but an improved understanding of charge carriers in mol. materials promises a more targeted development of org. and hybrid org./inorg. (opto-)electronic devices.
      >> More from SciFinder ®

The Effects of Crystallinity on Charge Transport and the Structure of Sequentially Processed F4TCNQ-Doped Conjugated Polymer Films. Adv. Funct. Mater. 2017, 27, 1702654,  DOI: 10.1002/adfm.201702654

    87. 87
      Leclerc, M.; Fréchette, M.; Bergeron, J.-Y.; Ranger, M.; Lévesque, I.; Faïd, K. Chromic Phenomena in Neutral Polythiophene Derivatives. Macromol. Chem. Phys. 1996, 197, 2077– 2087,  DOI: 10.1002/macp.1996.021970701
      [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
      87
      Chromic phenomena in neutral polythiophene derivatives
      Leclerc, Mario; Frechette, Martin; Bergeron, Jean Yves; Ranger, Maxime; Levesque, Isabelle; Faid, Karim
      Macromolecular Chemistry and Physics (1996), 197 (7), 2077-2087CODEN: MCHPES; ISSN:1022-1352. (Huethig & Wepf)
      Thermochromic phenomena in various regioregular and non-regioregular polythiophene derivs. were investigated both in the solid state and in soln. These studies have revealed the existence of 2 different types of thermochromic phenomena which are correlated to the substitution pattern of the polymers. Formation of delocalized conformational defects (twistons) was obsd. in regioregular polythiophene derivs. but do not occur in non-regioregular polythiophenes. For the latter polymers, only localized conformational defects can be created along the polymer backbone leading to a monotonic blue shift of the absorption max. upon heating. All these optical features are driven by order-disorder transitions of the side-chains, side-chain disordering increasing their steric hindrance and/or disrupting short-range ordered assemblies, which then force the thiophene backbone to adopt a nonplanar conformation. Non-covalent interactions between alkali metal ions and regioregular ether-substituted polythiophenes can modify the side-chain organization and can lead to interesting ionochromic effects. Chromic phenomena can be induced via a large range of external stimuli which should lead to the development of novel affinity-chromic and photochromic materials.

      A new standard method to calculate electrochromic switching time
      Hassab, Sofiane; Shen, D. Eric; Osterholm, Anna M.; Da Rocha, Mathias; Song, Giljoo; Alesanco, Yolanda; Vinuales, Ana; Rougier, Aline; Reynolds, John R.; Padilla, Javier
      Solar Energy Materials & Solar Cells (2018), 185 (), 54-60CODEN: SEMCEQ; ISSN:0927-0248. (Elsevier B.V.)
      The switching time is one of the key parameters used to assess the performance of an electrochromic material or device. In spite of its importance, there is currently no std. for how this parameter is defined, and as a result, it is difficult to compare switching time data between different research groups, and to quantify and assess reported improvements. We propose a std. method for reporting electrochromic switching times, based on straightforward exptl. fittings resulting in an anal. expression that can directly correlate obtainable optical contrast values with their corresponding switching times. This anal. expression makes it possible to unambiguously define the performance of an electrochromic material or device using two parameters: a full-switch contrast and a time const.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC1cXpsVGisrY%253D&md5=37041a9a190e63d4f94c26e1717a7b0f
    90. 90
      Brown, P. J.; Thomas, D. S.; Köhler, A.; Wilson, J. S.; Kim, J.-S.; Ramsdale, C. M.; Sirringhaus, H.; Friend, R. H. Effect of Interchain Interactions on the Absorption and Emission of Poly(3-hexylthiophene). Phys. Rev. B: Condens. Matter Mater. Phys. 2003, 67, 064203,  DOI: 10.1103/PhysRevB.67.064203
      [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
      90
      Effect of interchain interactions on the absorption and emission of poly(3-hexyl-thiophene)
      Brown, Peter J.; Thomas, D. Steve; Kohler, Anna; Wilson, Joanne S.; Kim, Ji-Seon; Ramsdale, Catherine M.; Sirringhaus, Henning; Friend, Richard H.
      Physical Review B: Condensed Matter and Materials Physics (2003), 67 (6), 064203/1-064203/16CODEN: PRBMDO; ISSN:0163-1829. (American Physical Society)
      The absorption spectrum of polythiophene and its deriv. poly(3-hexyl-thiophene) (P3HT) is usually described in terms of an intrachain exciton coupled to a single phonon mode. We show that this model is too simplistic for highly ordered, regio-regular P3HT and that, analogous to the case of charged polarons in this material, interchain interactions must be taken into account to correctly describe the absorption spectrum. We show that the lowest energy feature in the π-π* region of the absorption spectrum is assocd. with an interchain absorption, the intensity of which is correlated with the degree of order in the polymer. Correspondingly, we show that the emission from P3HT also exhibits contributions from both interchain and intrachain states, in a manner similar to that recently shown for poly(phenylenevinylene). Having reinterpreted the phys. origin of the features in the absorption and emission spectra of P3HT, we then model these spectra and show how they evolve as the degree of order in the polymer is changed by varying several phys. parameters including temp. and regio regularity of the polymer.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD3sXitV2rt78%253D&md5=9026111e649a817f15b62cc5f678f333
    91. 91
      Österholm, A. M.; Ponder, J. F.; De Keersmaecker, M.; Shen, D. E.; Reynolds, J. R. Disentangling Redox Properties and Capacitance in Solution-Processed Conjugated Polymers. Chem. Mater. 2019, 31, 2971– 2982,  DOI: 10.1021/acs.chemmater.9b00528
      [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
      91
      Disentangling Redox Properties and Capacitance in Solution-Processed Conjugated Polymers
      Osterholm, Anna M.; Ponder, James F.; De Keersmaecker, Michel; Shen, D. Eric; Reynolds, John R.
      Chemistry of Materials (2019), 31 (8), 2971-2982CODEN: CMATEX; ISSN:0897-4756. (American Chemical Society)
      The unique ability of combined ionic and electronic transport in conjugated, semiconducting polymers has resulted in the emergence of a variety of redox-based technologies ranging from energy storage and conversion, to bioelectronics, to on-demand color control. Although conjugated polymers have been extensively studied for decades, the recent revival of org. bioelectronics, in particular, has demonstrated that there needs to be a better understanding of the interplay between mixed ion and electron transport and the underlying film morphol. Many of the conjugated polymers that are effectively doped electrochem. and that exhibit a combination of high capacitance, fast and reversible redox switching, and exceptional stability lack long-range order making it more challenging to evaluate how the morphol. evolves as a function of oxidn. state. Here, we demonstrate how readily accessible electrochem. and spectroscopic techniques can offer a great deal of insight into ion and electron transport in redox-active conjugated polymers regardless of their degree of order. Furthermore, we show how numerous redox properties, including onset of oxidn., capacitance, and conductance profile, of five dioxythiophene-based copolymers can be manipulated by the size and polarity of the functional groups that are incorporated to provide soln. processability.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC1MXmsVagsr0%253D&md5=ef1b69e3039d0a58eb15553c85d7a7aa

      1. 1
        Ibanez, J. G.; Rincón, M. E.; Gutierrez-Granados, S.; Chahma, M. h.; Jaramillo-Quintero, O. A.; Frontana-Uribe, B. A. Conducting Polymers in the Fields of Energy, Environmental Remediation, and Chemical–Chiral Sensors. Chem. Rev. 2018, 118, 4731– 4816,  DOI: 10.1021/acs.chemrev.7b00482
        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
        1
        Conducting Polymers in the Fields of Energy, Environmental Remediation, and Chemical-Chiral Sensors
        Ibanez, Jorge G.; Rincon, Marina. E.; Gutierrez-Granados, Silvia; Chahma, M'hamed; Jaramillo-Quintero, Oscar A.; Frontana-Uribe, Bernardo A.
        Chemical Reviews (Washington, DC, United States) (2018), 118 (9), 4731-4816CODEN: CHREAY; ISSN:0009-2665. (American Chemical Society)
        A review. Conducting polymers (CPs) thanks to their unique properties, structures made on-demand, new composite mixts. and possibility of deposit on a surface by chem., phys. or electrochem. methodologies, have shown in the last years a renaissance and were widely used in important fields of chem. and materials science. Due to the extensive of the literature of CPs, this review, after a concise introduction about the interrelationship between electrochem. and conducting polymers, it is focused exclusively on the following applications: energy (energy storage devices and solar cells), its use in environmental remediation (anion and cation trapping, electrocatalytic redn./oxidn. of pollutants on CP based electrodes and adsorption of pollutants) and finally electroanal. as chem. sensors in soln., gas phase and chiral mols. This review is expected to be a comprehensive, authoritative, and useful to the chem. community interested in CPs and its applications.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC1cXntFahu74%253D&md5=03f5131b5224a87a6fad289799d63c88
      2. 2
        Bryan, A. M.; Santino, L. M.; Lu, Y.; Acharya, S.; D’Arcy, J. M. Conducting Polymers for Pseudocapacitive Energy Storage. Chem. Mater. 2016, 28, 5989– 5998,  DOI: 10.1021/acs.chemmater.6b01762
        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
        2
        Conducting Polymers for Pseudocapacitive Energy Storage
        Bryan, Aimee M.; Santino, Luciano M.; Lu, Yang; Acharya, Shinjita; D'Arcy, Julio M.
        Chemistry of Materials (2016), 28 (17), 5989-5998CODEN: CMATEX; ISSN:0897-4756. (American Chemical Society)
        Developing energy storage devices to be utilized within a rapidly advancing energy market requires a multipronged approach whereby material synthesis and engineering fundamentals combine to enable technol. advances. These devices should be able to store a large amt. of energy in a small, lightwt. package, and should be able to distribute that energy quickly for high rate applications. Pseudocapacitors made from conducting polymers, which store charge via rapid redn. and oxidn. reactions, are a particularly promising candidate. This perspective explores cond. and charge storage mechanisms in conducting polymers and describes how synthetic strategies can affect these properties. Chem. correlations are further developed that were shown to enhance the performance of pseudocapacitive electrochem. capacitors fabricated from conducting polymers. Important device engineering strategies for improving the lifetime and applicability of pseudocapacitors are also discussed.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC28Xht1Cisr7P&md5=cf9a9155301b4a1be1cc96e7dd477b04
      3. 3
        Kaloni, T. P.; Giesbrecht, P. K.; Schreckenbach, G.; Freund, M. S. Polythiophene: From Fundamental Perspectives to Applications. Chem. Mater. 2017, 29, 10248– 10283,  DOI: 10.1021/acs.chemmater.7b03035
        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
        3
        Polythiophene: From Fundamental Perspectives to Applications
        Kaloni, Thaneshwor P.; Giesbrecht, Patrick K.; Schreckenbach, Georg; Freund, Michael S.
        Chemistry of Materials (2017), 29 (24), 10248-10283CODEN: CMATEX; ISSN:0897-4756. (American Chemical Society)
        A review. The field of org. electronics has been heavily impacted by the discovery and development of π-conjugated conducting polymers. These polymers show great potential for integration into future optical and electronic devices due to their capacity to transition between semiconducting and conducting states as well as the ability to alter mech. properties by controlled doping, chem. modification, and by stacking or creating composites with other materials. Among π-conjugated polymers, polythiophene and its derivs. has been one of the most extensively studied and is widely investigated computationally and exptl. for use in electronic devices such as light emitting diodes, water purifn. devices, hydrogen storage, biosensors. Various theor. modeling studies of polythiophene ranging from an oligothiophene approach to infinite chain lengths (periodic boundary conditions) have been undertaken in order to study a variety of electronic and structural properties of these polymers. In this review, we discuss the recent advances in the understanding of pristine polythiophene and its derivs. from fundamental perspectives to device applications.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2sXhvFGiur7I&md5=edeb6f8cf557f14d972e2be1accdcc31
      4. 4
        Beaujuge, P. M.; Reynolds, J. R. Color Control in π-Conjugated Organic Polymers for Use in Electrochromic Devices. Chem. Rev. 2010, 110, 268– 320,  DOI: 10.1021/cr900129a
        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
        4
        Color Control in π-Conjugated Organic Polymers for Use in Electrochromic Devices
        Beaujuge, Pierre M.; Reynolds, John R.
        Chemical Reviews (Washington, DC, United States) (2010), 110 (1), 268-320CODEN: CHREAY; ISSN:0009-2665. (American Chemical Society)
        A review is given on electrochromic properties of polymers. Such topics as coloration efficiency, colorimetric and reflection anal., switching rate, stability and memory effects are discussed. Data for cathodically and anodically colored polymers are reported. Electrochromic devices and their fabrication and materials used are described. A wide range of polymers used in ECDs are reviewed.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC3cXivFKrug%253D%253D&md5=ed1aadeb141f3baef9a90068f9f67ce7
      5. 5
        Li, X.; Perera, K.; He, J.; Gumyusenge, A.; Mei, J. Solution-Processable Electrochromic Materials and Devices: Roadblocks and Strategies Towards Large-Scale Applications. J. Mater. Chem. C 2019, 7, 12761– 12789,  DOI: 10.1039/c9tc02861g
        [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
        5
        Solution-processable electrochromic materials and devices: roadblocks and strategies towards large-scale applications
        Li, Xuefei; Perera, Kuluni; He, Jiazhi; Gumyusenge, Aristide; Mei, Jianguo
        Journal of Materials Chemistry C: Materials for Optical and Electronic Devices (2019), 7 (41), 12761-12789CODEN: JMCCCX; ISSN:2050-7534. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
        A review. Electrochromic devices (ECDs) that modulate optical transmission or reflection in a controllable manner are attractive in energy-saving and color-tuning applications. In this review, we discuss the key components, fundamental working principles and performance metrics of ECDs using layman's terms. We also highlight recent materials development of each component and illustrate how the structure-property relationships impact their processability, device performance and stability. We further introduce emerging materials that exhibit electrochromic properties, and discuss the transition from lab.-scale, half-cell-based characterizations of electrochromic materials to the fabrication of solid-state electrochromic devices and evaluation of their performances. Finally, we lay out major challenges for fabricating large-scale and cost-effective ECDs, particularly the materials design and fabrication strategies for achieving chem. and electrochem. stable, high performance ECDs that can be produced by roll-to-roll techniques.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC1MXhsFerurbJ&md5=b68bc6a20741c31cf08b9e1a80f48465

        Österholm, A. M.; Shen, D. E.; Reynolds, J. R. Electrochromism in Conjugated Polymer-Strategies for Complete and Straightfoward Color Control. In Handbook of Conducting Polymers, 4th ed.; Reynolds, J., Thompson, B., Skothelm, T., Eds.; CRC Press: Boca Routon, 2019; Vol. 4.

      8. 8
        Lo, C. K.; Shen, D. E.; Reynolds, J. R. Fine-Tuning the Color Hue of π-Conjugated Black-to-Clear Electrochromic Random Copolymers. Macromolecules 2019, 52, 6773– 6779,  DOI: 10.1021/acs.macromol.9b01443
        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
        8
        Fine-Tuning the Color Hue of π-Conjugated Black-to-Clear Electrochromic Random Copolymers
        Lo, Chi Kin; Shen, D. Eric; Reynolds, John R.
        Macromolecules (Washington, DC, United States) (2019), 52 (17), 6773-6779CODEN: MAMOBX; ISSN:0024-9297. (American Chemical Society)
        A family of dioxythiophene (DOT)-based conjugated random copolymers, capable of reversibly switching between a neutral black and an oxidized transmissive state, are reported for electrochromic (EC) applications. By replacing 3,4-ethylenedioxythiophene (EDOT) in the previous generation of a core donor-acceptor-donor (D-A-D) terheterocycle with a methyl-alkylated 3,4-propylenedioxythiophene (ProDOT), we enhance the soly. of precursors and monomers in this new generation of broadly absorbing electrochromic polymers (ECPs). By adjusting the newly designed terheterocycle monomer feed ratio, we obtain three polymers with varying hues of color neutrality (a* and b* < ±10) throughout the entire switching voltage range and with integrated contrasts 45-49% throughout the visible region (380-700 nm). The a* values of the polymers ranged between -8 (green hue) and +5 (red hue), with their b* values ranging between -4 and -7 (blue hue) in their neutral states; addnl., the a* and b* values are all below ±8 in their oxidized states. In electrochromic devices (ECDs), we exploit this variation in color hue to achieve color balance with the counter electrode material-a minimal color-changing polymer (MCCP) that is colorless in its fully neutral and oxidized states but light red at intermediate potentials. This red hue was balanced by the green hue of ECP-Random40, leading to an ECD that was color-neutral (a* ranging from -0.8 to -11 and b* ranging from -0.5 to 1.7) throughout the switching voltage range. This family of high-contrast and color-neutral ECPs are scalable with high yielding syntheses for all monomers due to the enhancement of monomer soly. and the usage of commonly available DOT moieties, which will aid in advancing the development of large-scale polymer-based EC window and display applications. This method provides materials that switch from black to transmissive through only gray intermediates as needed for switchable color tinting applications.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC1MXhs1Grsr%252FO&md5=b837f993418f0e9c78ed925a799d2c5a

        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar

        Donor-acceptor type random copolymers for full visible light absorption
        Oktem Gozde; Balan Abidin; Baran Derya; Toppare Levent
        Chemical communications (Cambridge, England) (2011), 47 (13), 3933-5 ISSN:.
        Copolymerization towards obtaining full visible light absorption is highlighted. Randomly distributed segments of different oligomers resulted in neutral state black copolymers. Solution processability and highly transmissive gray oxidized states make copolymers great candidates to be used in low cost flexible organic electronics.

        Neo, W. T.; Cho, C. M.; Shi, Z.; Chua, S.-J.; Xu, J. Modulating High-Energy Visible Light Absorption to Attain Neutral-State Black Electrochromic Polymers. J. Mater. Chem. C 2016, 4, 28– 32,  DOI: 10.1039/c5tc02883c

        10
        Modulating high-energy visible light absorption to attain neutral-state black electrochromic polymers
        Neo, Wei Teng; Cho, Ching Mui; Shi, Zugui; Chua, Soo-Jin; Xu, Jianwei
        Journal of Materials Chemistry C: Materials for Optical and Electronic Devices (2016), 4 (1), 28-32CODEN: JMCCCX; ISSN:2050-7534. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
        Neutral-state black diketopyrrolopyrrole (DPP)-based conjugated polymers with the color channels a* from -3 to 0 and b* from -2 to -7 are achieved by incorporating an addnl. donor segment - dialkoxythiophene (DalkOT), which leads to the enhancement in blue-wavelength absorption. The polymers display black-to-transmissive gray electrochromic switching with good redox stability.

      11. 11
        Chen, C.; Yan, Q. Achieving Excellent Colorimetric Properties of Low-Cost Black to Transmissive Switching Electrochromic Polymers by Incorporating of Spacing Units into Copolymers of 3,4-Propylenedioxythiophene and Benzothiadiazole. Dyes Pigm. 2020, 178, 108378,  DOI: 10.1016/j.dyepig.2020.108378
        [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
        11
        Achieving excellent colorimetric properties of low-cost black to transmissive switching electrochromic polymers by incorporating of spacing units into copolymers of 3,4-propylenedioxythiophene and benzothiadiazole
        Chen, Cheng; Yan, Qifan
        Dyes and Pigments (2020), 178 (), 108378CODEN: DYPIDX; ISSN:0143-7208. (Elsevier Ltd.)
        There have been increasing research attention directed towards black to transmissive switching electrochromic polymers, few reports employed simple polymers with a low prodn. cost. Herein, we report the prepn. of a series of polymers P2-P6 by incorporating different spacing units (i.e. carbazole, naphthalene, and phenylene) into the well-studied polymer P1, a copolymer of 3,4-propylenedioxythiophene (ProDOT) and benzothiadiazole (BTD). Simple prepn. of polymers P2-P6 with spacing units were realized via C-H arylation polymn. between corresponding monomers, which are readily available. By inserting such phenyl-ring contg. spacing units into oligoProDOT moieties, conjugation between ProDOT units was disrupted. Thus, polymers P2-P6 based electrochromic devices show a new absorption peak in short wavelength region (400 nm-500 nm) resulting a* andxb* values (<±10), which are closer to a true black hue than that of P1 (-1.2, -15.39) in neutral state. Meanwhile, we demonstrate that the colorimetric properties of P4 (0.32, -6.43) and P6 (-0.06, -4.26) are better performing than most existing black polymers.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BB3cXmt1Gguro%253D&md5=6b26f5d52ab959a2277587bf40ed8fb5
      12. 12
        Bini, K.; Murto, P.; Elmas, S.; Andersson, M. R.; Wang, E. Broad Spectrum Absorption and Low-Voltage Electrochromic Operation from Indacenodithieno[3,2-b]thiophene-Based Copolymers. Polym. Chem. 2019, 10, 2004– 2014,  DOI: 10.1039/c8py01787e
        [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
        12
        Broad spectrum absorption and low-voltage electrochromic operation from indacenodithieno[3,2-b]thiophene-based copolymers
        Bini, Kim; Murto, Petri; Elmas, Sait; Andersson, Mats R.; Wang, Ergang
        Polymer Chemistry (2019), 10 (16), 2004-2014CODEN: PCOHC2; ISSN:1759-9962. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
        Electrochromic performance of conjugated polymers has quickly become an important design factor in a variety of applications. There is still significant need to develop highly stable materials with high optical contrast, desired color switching and fast kinetics. Here, poly[indacenodithieno[3,2-b]thiophene-2,8-diyl] (PIDTT) is introduced as a new type of electrochromic polymer exhibiting a narrow absorption band, excellent electrochem. stability and fast color switching kinetics between vibrant red (peak max. at ∼550 nm) and transparent (peak max. at ∼920 nm) within a low potential range of 0-0.8 V. To widen the spectral coverage of the well-functioning PIDTT over the entire visible range, a modified donor-acceptor approach is used by incorporating three different donor-acceptor-donor (DAD) segments into an indacenodithieno[3,2-b]thiophene (IDTT) based polymer backbone, so as to obtain three different alternating copolymers. This design motif is further rationalized by the maintained electrochem. stability of the new copolymers, and their full color switching between black and transparent down to an ultra-low potential range of 0-0.6 V.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC1MXks1Slsbg%253D&md5=3659b179c8ec82de69978c28a4160ec7
      13. 13
        Li, W.; Ning, J.; Yin, Y.; Xing, X.; Qi, M.; Li, T.; Cao, J.; He, Y.; Perepichka, I. F.; Meng, H. Thieno[3,2-b]thiophene-Based Conjugated Copolymers for Solution-Processable Neutral Black Electrochromism. Polym. Chem. 2018, 9, 5608– 5616,  DOI: 10.1039/c8py01208c
        [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
        13
        Thieno[3,2-b]thiophene-based conjugated copolymers for solution-processable neutral black electrochromism
        Li, Weishuo; Ning, Jiaoyi; Yin, Yuyang; Xing, Xing; Qi, Maowei; Li, Tingting; Cao, Jupeng; He, Yaowu; Perepichka, Igor F.; Meng, Hong
        Polymer Chemistry (2018), 9 (47), 5608-5616CODEN: PCOHC2; ISSN:1759-9962. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
        In the quest for ideal color and performance of black electrochromism, two soln.-processable neutral black electrochromic copolymers, PTTBTPh0.35 and PTTBTTh0.30, were prepd. through facile direct (hetero)arylation polymn. Both copolymers exhibit a favorable black color with broad absorption across the visible range of the spectrum and PTTBTPh0.35 shows quite high color neutrality with CIE 1976 coordinates (L* = 37.23; a* = -1.59; b* = 0.32). Moreover, both the copolymers reveal desirable electrochromic performances of fast switching within ≤1 s, high optical contrasts over 35% and considerable color efficiencies around 200 cm2 C-1, appearing to be promising candidates for electrochromic displays. Addnl., reliable electroactivity and high contrast in the NIR region make them applicable in energy storage and smart windows.

      14. 14
        Christiansen, D. T.; Ohtani, S.; Chujo, Y.; Tomlinson, A. L.; Reynolds, J. R. All Donor Electrochromic Polymers Tunable across the Visible Spectrum via Random Copolymerization. Chem. Mater. 2019, 31, 6841– 6849,  DOI: 10.1021/acs.chemmater.9b01293
        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
        14
        All Donor Electrochromic Polymers Tunable across the Visible Spectrum via Random Copolymerization
        Christiansen, Dylan T.; Ohtani, Shunsuke; Chujo, Yoshiki; Tomlinson, Aimee L.; Reynolds, John R.
        Chemistry of Materials (2019), 31 (17), 6841-6849CODEN: CMATEX; ISSN:0897-4756. (American Chemical Society)
        A series of conjugated, random terpolymers based on all donor repeat units are prepd. via direct (hetero)arylation polymn. yielding cathodically colored electrochromic polymers that span the visible spectrum. The polymers are based on repeat units of a dialkylthiophene, a 3,4-propylenedioxythiophene, and dimers of 3,4-ethylenedioxythiophene. Using a tight feedback loop between computational and exptl. chem., the colors of these polymers are controllably tuned to cover the visible spectrum by controlling the monomer ratios. Examns. via UV-visible-near-IR spectroscopy, differential pulse voltammetry, spectroelectrochem., and colorimetry show that, while these systems can vary greatly in their spectral properties, their oxidn. potentials are all low (<0.5 V vs Ag/AgCl). The color tunability allows for access to neutral state orange, red, pink, magenta, purple, and blue polymers of various hues with a* values ranging from 22 to 35 and b* values ranging from -44 to 45, while maintaining highly transmissive oxidized states. This approach allows access to a wide gamut of colors with only three monomers while affording materials with low oxidn. potentials and high contrast.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC1MXhtFKgtb7L&md5=608bd4f3489a56b2c25056a841d4dd4b
      15. 15
        Österholm, A. M.; Shen, D. E.; Kerszulis, J. A.; Bulloch, R. H.; Kuepfert, M.; Dyer, A. L.; Reynolds, J. R. Four Shades of Brown: Tuning of Electrochromic Polymer Blends Toward High-Contrast Eyewear. ACS Appl. Mater. Interfaces 2015, 7, 1413– 1421,  DOI: 10.1021/am507063d
        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
        15
        Four shades of brown: Tuning of electrochromic polymer blends toward high-contrast eyewear
        Osterholm, Anna M.; Shen, D. Eric; Kerszulis, Justin A.; Bulloch, Rayford H.; Kuepfert, Michael; Dyer, Aubrey L.; Reynolds, John R.
        ACS Applied Materials & Interfaces (2015), 7 (3), 1413-1421CODEN: AAMICK; ISSN:1944-8244. (American Chemical Society)
        We report a straightforward strategy of accessing a wide variety of colors through simple predictive color mixing of electrochromic polymers (ECPs). We have created a set of brown ECP blends that can be incorporated as the active material in user-controlled electrochromic eyewear. Color mixing of ECPs proceeds in a subtractive fashion, and we acquire various hues of brown through the mixing of cyan and yellow primaries in combination with orange and periwinkle-blue secondary colors. Upon oxidn., all of the created blends exhibit a change in transmittance from ca. 10 to 70% in a few seconds. We demonstrate the attractiveness of these ECP blends as active materials in electrochromic eyewear by assembling user-controlled, high-contrast, fast-switching, and fully soln.-processable electrochromic lenses with colorless transmissive states and colored states that correspond to com. available sunglasses. The lenses were fabricated using a combination of inkjet printing and blade-coating to illustrate the feasibility of using sol. ECPs for high-throughput and large-scale processing.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2MXlsFGmsw%253D%253D&md5=1b8cd65578e4073fce12becc0b338410

      17. 17
        Sassi, M.; Salamone, M. M.; Ruffo, R.; Patriarca, G. E.; Mari, C. M.; Pagani, G. A.; Posset, U.; Beverina, L. State-of-the-Art Neutral Tint Multichromophoric Polymers for High-Contrast See-Through Electrochromic Devices. Adv. Funct. Mater. 2016, 26, 5240– 5246,  DOI: 10.1002/adfm.201601819
        [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
        17
        State-of-the-Art Neutral Tint Multichromophoric Polymers for High-Contrast See-Through Electrochromic Devices
        Sassi, Mauro; Salamone, Matteo M.; Ruffo, Riccardo; Patriarca, Giorgio E.; Mari, Claudio M.; Pagani, Giorgio A.; Posset, Uwe; Beverina, Luca
        Advanced Functional Materials (2016), 26 (29), 5240-5246CODEN: AFMDC6; ISSN:1616-301X. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
        Two new multichromophoric electrochromic polymers featuring a conjugated EDOT/ProDOT copolymer backbone (PXDOT) and a reversible Weitz-type redox active small mol. electrochrome (WTE) tethered to the conjugated chain are reported here. The careful design of the WTEs provides a highly reversible redox behavior with a colorless red switching that complements the colorless blue switching of the conjugated backbone. Subtractive color mixing successfully provides high performing soln. processable polymeric layers with colorless neutral tint switchable limiting states for application in see-through electrochromic devices. Design, synthesis, comprehensive chem. and spectroelectrochem. characterization as well as the prepn. of a proof-of-concept device are discussed.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC28XhtVahsLnO&md5=9a0c5da50438688c64ef6ef1d82f2d9d

        Lee, K.-R.; Sotzing, G. A. Color Tuning of Black for Electrochromic Polymers Using Precursor Blends. Chem. Commun. 2013, 49, 5192– 5194,  DOI: 10.1039/c3cc41584h
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        18
        Color tuning of black for electrochromic polymers using precursor blends
        Lee, Ki-Ryong; Sotzing, Gregory A.
        Chemical Communications (Cambridge, United Kingdom) (2013), 49 (45), 5192-5194CODEN: CHCOFS; ISSN:1359-7345. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
        A facile controlling of the optical and colorimetric properties of a donor-acceptor conjugated polymer was demonstrated simply by varying the mix ratio of two precursors in a precursor blend. The conversion of a precursor blend results in an entirely new donor-acceptor polymer, distinct from the conjugated polymer of each precursor. Careful optimization of the mix ratio of two precursors results in a black electrochromic polymer.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC3sXnsFart70%253D&md5=a44ebab7be6cc6cc70a2671adee2124f
      19. 19
        Xu, Z.; Wang, W.; Wu, J.; Mi, S.; Zheng, J.; Xu, C. Black-to-Transmissive Electrochromic Switching Polymer Films via Solution Co-Processing. New J. Chem. 2016, 40, 5231– 5237,  DOI: 10.1039/c5nj03023d
        [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
        19
        Black-to-transmissive electrochromic switching polymer films via solution co-processing
        Xu, Zhangping; Wang, Wenjing; Wu, Jingchuan; Mi, Sai; Zheng, Jianming; Xu, Chunye
        New Journal of Chemistry (2016), 40 (6), 5231-5237CODEN: NJCHE5; ISSN:1144-0546. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
        A pair of soln.-processable electrochromic polymers poly(2,3-bis(3,4-bis(dodecyloxy)phenyl)-5,8-bis(2,3-dihydrothieno[3,4-b][1,4]dioxin-5-yl)quinoxaline) (P1) and poly(3,4-di(2-ethylhexyloxy)thiophene-co-3,4-dibutoxythiophene) (P2) were designed and synthesized through a chem. oxidative polymn. and copolymn. approach. According to color mixing theory, the two polymers with complementary colors (green for P1 and purple-red for P2) were utilized to create black-to-transmissive switching films via co-processing from a soln. contg. them in an appropriate mass ratio. The films exhibit a deep black color, moderate optical contrast and robust stability. This method and the films with favorable electrochromic performances could be employed for the realization of potential large area electrochromic device applications.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC28XmsFCgu7Y%253D&md5=d292ce8f73d9228e1375b612bb71a20d
      20. 20
        Li, M.; Yassin, O. A.; Baczkowski, M. L.; Zhang, X.; Daniels, R.; Deshmukh, A. A.; Zhu, Y.; Otley, M. T.; Sotzing, G. A. Colorless to Black Electrochromic Devices using Subtractive Color Mixing of Two Electrochromes: A Conjugated Polymer with a Small Organic Molecule. Org. Electron. 2020, 84, 105748,  DOI: 10.1016/j.orgel.2020.105748
        [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
        20
        Colorless to black electrochromic devices using subtractive color mixing of two electrochromes: A conjugated polymer with a small organic molecule
        Li, Mengfang; Yassin, Omer A.; Baczkowski, Matthew L.; Zhang, Xiaozheng; Daniels, Robert; Deshmukh, Ajinkya A.; Zhu, Yumin; Otley, Michael T.; Sotzing, Gregory A.
        Organic Electronics (2020), 84 (), 105748CODEN: OERLAU; ISSN:1566-1199. (Elsevier B.V.)
        Herein, we present a facile method for color-tuning an electrochromic device that switched between two neutral colors through simple color mixing of a conjugated polymer, poly(2,2-dimethyl-3,4-propylenedioxythiophene) and an electrochromic small mol. arom. diester, diethyl-4,4'-biphenyldicarboxylate. The resulting device had a photopic contrast of ca. 57% across the visible spectrum. In addn., the device exhibited color uniformity and stability over 2,000 switches. Using these mixed coloring materials, a large area electrochromic device of 140 cm2 was fabricated, exceeding the size of ophthalmic lenses and small displays.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BB3cXhtVCqsLvL&md5=a39bbadf6eda2a39e5d806091c384a87
      21. 21
        Yu, X.; Chang, M.; Chen, W.; Liang, D.; Lu, X.; Zhou, G. Colorless-to-Black Electrochromism from Binary Electrochromes toward Multifunctional Displays. ACS Appl. Mater. Interfaces 2020, 12, 39505– 39514,  DOI: 10.1021/acsami.0c11840
        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
        21
        Colorless-to-Black Electrochromism from Binary Electrochromes toward Multifunctional Displays
        Yu Xuewen; Chang Meijuan; Chen Weinan; Liang Dingli; Zhou Gang; Lu Xuefeng
        ACS applied materials & interfaces (2020), 12 (35), 39505-39514 ISSN:.
        Cyclohexane-1,2,4,5-tetracarboxylic diimide with a nonconjugated core has been incorporated to bridge two conventional triphenylamine units. The obtained monomer has successfully hypsochromically shifted the maximum absorption wavelength by 10 nm in comparison to the one with a pyromellitic diimide bridge. Consequently, a colorless electrochromic (EC) polymer poly(bis(N,N-diphenyl-4-aminophenyl)cyclohexane-1,2,4,5-tetracarboxylic diimide) (PTPA-HDI) was electropolymerized on indium tin oxide (ITO)-coated glass. The morphology, absorption, and spectroelectrochemistry properties of polymer PTPA-HDI films electropolymerized by different scan cycles have been systematically investigated. It is found that comprehensive properties, such as color contrast and initial transparence, can be achieved for the polymer film electropolymerized by 15 scan cycles. Moreover, to realize colorless-to-black electrochromism, an asymmetric viologen derivative 1-(4-cyanophenyl)-1'-hexyl-4,4'-bipyridinium dihexafluorophosphate (HVCN) has been designed and straightforward synthesized. With the introduction of a cyanophenyl group and a hexyl chain on the two pyridinium units, colorless-to-green electrochromism can be realized for this processible viologen derivative. The absorption band at 495 nm of colorated PTPA-HDI compensates well for the valley in the absorption spectrum of colorated HVCN. Therefore, different types of colorless-to-black electrochromic devices (ECDs) are fabricated using polymer PTPA-HDI-deposited ITO electrode and HVCN-based gel electrolyte. Such a supporting electrolyte-free ECD with binary electrochromes exhibits fast coloration, high color contrast, and excellent reversibility. Furthermore, an encryption ECD is demonstrated by switching a black two-dimensional code. In addition, an autodigital display is integrated on a smart window and hence different functions can be realized in a single ECD. Overall, this study may facilitate the understanding of the EC behaviors of binary electrochromes and present a new path to design multifunctional displays.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A280%3ADC%252BB38fmsFelug%253D%253D&md5=e04ec197269f8d1109097ea61e067b09
      22. 22
        Yen, H.-J.; Liou, G.-S. Solution-Processable Triarylamine-Based Electroactive High Performance Polymers for Anodically Electrochromic Applications. Polym. Chem. 2012, 3, 255– 264,  DOI: 10.1039/c1py00346a
        [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
        22
        Solution-processable triarylamine-based electroactive high performance polymers for anodically electrochromic applications
        Yen, Hung-Ju; Liou, Guey-Sheng
        Polymer Chemistry (2012), 3 (2), 255-264CODEN: PCOHC2; ISSN:1759-9962. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
        A review. This review focused on high-performance polymers with anodically electrochromic triarylamine units built into main chains or as pendants. The main aim of the review is to present the most important and common trends regarding polymer synthesis from the point of view of the introduction of triarylamine moiety into polymer chains and to demonstrate how the polymer structures influence their properties, which leads them to be suitable for optoelectronic device construction. This review also covers a majority of the works in the recent decade involving the synthesis and characteristic evaluation of the resulting electrochromic polymers and their structural design by using the resp. monomers.
        >> More from SciFinder ®

        23
        Toward the development of new textile/plastic electrochromic cells using triphenylamine-based copolymers
        Beaupre, Serge; Dumas, Jean; Leclerc, Mario
        Chemistry of Materials (2006), 18 (17), 4011-4018CODEN: CMATEX; ISSN:0897-4756. (American Chemical Society)
        Electrochromic polymers contg. a 4-butyltriphenylamine (BuTPA) unit on the main chain are prepd. and characterized. All polymers were obtained through the Suzuki-Miyaura cross-coupling reaction between 4-butyl-N,N-bis((4,4,5,5-tetramethyl-1,3,2-dioxaborolan-4-phenyl)aniline) and several aryl dibromide mols. to modulate the electronic properties of the resulting copolymers. 2,5-Dibromothiophene, 2,5-dibromo(3,4-ethylenedioxythiophene), 3,6-dibromo-N-octylcarbazole, bis(6-bromo-N-octylcarbazol-3-yl), and 2,7-dibromo-3,6-dimethoxy-9,9-dihexylfluorene were used as comonomers and led to five new copolymers, PT(BuTPA), PE(BuTPA), PC(BuTPA), PCC(BuTPA), and PF(BuTPA). These polymers are readily sol. in many common org. solvents, which make them suitable for spray-coating film deposition. Electrochromic cells with the following configuration were assembled: ITO-coated glass or plastic/electrochromic polymer/gel electrolyte/ITO-coated glass or plastic or conducting textile. These copolymers exhibit good optical and electrochem. properties for military camouflage needs with color transition from pale yellow to green, transparent to khaki, or pale green to reddish-brown. Electrochem., spectroelectrochem., and colorimetric measurements of the devices were examd.

        Jeong, J.; Kumar, R. S.; Naveen, M.; Son, Y.-A. Synthesis and Characterization of Triphenylamine-Based Polymers and Their Application Towards Solid-State Electrochromic Cells. RSC Adv. 2016, 6, 78984– 78993,  DOI: 10.1039/c6ra12112h

        Synthesis and characterization of triphenylamine-based polymers and their application towards solid-state electrochromic cells
        Jeong, Jaemyeng; Kumar, Rangaraju Satish; Naveen, Mergu; Son, Young-A.
        RSC Advances (2016), 6 (82), 78984-78993CODEN: RSCACL; ISSN:2046-2069. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
        Four novel triphenylamine-based polymers, PJK1, PJK2, PJK3 and PJK4 were successfully synthesized and fully characterized by 1H NMR, UV-VIS spectroscopy, cyclic voltammetry (CV), GPC and spectroelectrochem. These polymers are easily sol. in many common org. solvents, which make them appropriate for film deposition via spray-coating. We fabricated electrochromic cells comprising ITO-coated glass/polymer/gel electrolyte/ITO-coated glass and patterned the color change by applying d.c. with different voltages. We report herein color changes, from the neutral to oxidized form as follows: for PJK1, orange to dark green; for PJK2, light yellow to reddish brown; for PJK3, light blue to gray; and for PJK4, green to bluish green. The majority of the copolymers exhibited very good thermal stabilities, as evidenced by less than a 5% wt. loss in temps. exceeding 400°C. To further characterize, we simulated the electrochem. and optical properties, which are good agreement with the exptl. data.

        Novel triarylamine-based alternating conjugated polymer with high hole mobility: synthesis, electro-optical, and electronic properties
        Chen, Wen-Hsiang; Wang, Kun-Li; Hung, Wen-Yi; Jiang, Jyh-Chiang; Liaw, Der-Jang; Lee, Kueir-Rarn; Lai, Juin-Yih; Chen, Ci-Liang
        Journal of Polymer Science, Part A: Polymer Chemistry (2010), 48 (21), 4654-4667CODEN: JPACEC; ISSN:0887-624X. (John Wiley & Sons, Inc.)
        Novel bi-triphenylamine-contg. arom. dibromide M3, N,N-bis(4-bromophenyl)-N',N'-diphenyl-1,4-phenylenediamine, was successfully synthesized. The novel conjugated polymer P1 having no.-av. mol. wt. of 1.31 × 104 was prepd. via Suzuki coupling from the dibromide M3 and 9,9-dioctylfluorene-2,7-diboronic acid bis(1,3-propanediol) ester. Polymer P1 had excellent thermal stability assocd. with a high glass-transition temp. (Tg = 141°). The hole-transporting and UV-vis-near-IR electrochromic properties were examd. by electrochem. and spectroelectrochem. methods. Cyclic voltammograms of the conjugated polymer films cast onto indium-tin oxide-coated glass substrates exhibited two reversible oxidn. redox couples at E1/2 values of 0.73 and 1.13 V vs. Ag/Ag+ in acetonitrile soln. The hole mobility of the conjugated polymer P1 revealed ∼10-3 cm2 V-1 s-1, which is much higher than that of other conjugated polymer systems. The obsd. UV-vis-near-IR absorption change in the conjugated polymer film P1 at applied potentials ranging from 0.00 to 1.23 V are fully reversible and assocd. with strong color changes from pale yellowish in its neutral form to green and blue in its oxidized form. Using a combination of exptl. study and theor. study, we proposed an oxidn. mechanism based on MO theory, which explains the cyclic voltammetry exptl. results well.

        Dey, T.; Invernale, M. A.; Ding, Y.; Buyukmumcu, Z.; Sotzing, G. A. Poly(3,4-propylenedioxythiophene)s as a Single Platform for Full Color Realization. Macromolecules 2011, 44, 2415– 2417,  DOI: 10.1021/ma102580x

        26
        Poly(3,4-propylenedioxythiophene)s as a single platform for full color realization
        Dey, Tanmoy; Invernale, Michael A.; Ding, Yujie; Buyukmumcu, Zeki; Sotzing, Gregory A.
        Macromolecules (Washington, DC, United States) (2011), 44 (8), 2415-2417CODEN: MAMOBX; ISSN:0024-9297. (American Chemical Society)
        Author's have shown that 1,3-disubstituted ProDOT (poly propylenedioxythiophene) derivs. exhibit excellent characteristics for electrochromics (EC) applications, most notable being the 200 nm shift in λmax from P13ProDOTMe2. Fine tuning of color is possible by simply changing the size of the substituents at the 1,3-positions, which is one of the most important aspects of this system. A distinct structure-property relationship was obsd. for P13ProDOT-TB2, P13ProDOT-IP2, and P13ProDOT-Me2 with respect to conventional PPro-DOT-Me2. The bulky substituents used were designed to increase the soly. of the polymer without compromising the electrochromic properties. Currently, we are working on other derivs. in order to fully explore the color gamut that can be achieved by this method. This simple synthetic approach to color tuning will make it easier for electrochromic display applications, among other color-transition-based applications, to be realized in the future.

        Solid-State High-Throughput Screening for Color Tuning of Electrochromic Polymers

Demonstration and validation was established for a high-throughput screening method for prepg. a set of conjugated copolymers exhibiting a single absorption peak within the visible region in the colored state and a highly transmissive sky blue color in the bleached state.

        Propylenedioxythiophene (ProDOT)-phenylene copolymers allow a yellow-to-transmissive electrochrome
        Amb, Chad M.; Kerszulis, Justin A.; Thompson, Emily J.; Dyer, Aubrey L.; Reynolds, John R.

        In order to create multicolor displays using electrochromic (EC) technologies, the modulation of the intensity of three primary subtractive colors (red, yellow, blue, or cyan, magenta, yellow) could be used to express any color in the spectrum. Herein we report the first cathodically coloring yellow-to-transmissive switching EC polymer, which completes a full color palette and promises to fulfil the requirements necessary to create multicolor EC displays.

        Kerszulis, J. A.; Amb, C. M.; Dyer, A. L.; Reynolds, J. R. Follow the Yellow Brick Road: Structural Optimization of Vibrant Yellow-to-Transmissive Electrochromic Conjugated Polymers. Macromolecules 2014, 47, 5462– 5469,  DOI: 10.1021/ma501080u
        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
        29
        Follow the Yellow Brick Road: Structural Optimization of Vibrant Yellow-to-Transmissive Electrochromic Conjugated Polymers
        Kerszulis, Justin A.; Amb, Chad M.; Dyer, Aubrey L.; Reynolds, John R.
        Macromolecules (Washington, DC, United States) (2014), 47 (16), 5462-5469CODEN: MAMOBX; ISSN:0024-9297. (American Chemical Society)
        A series of conjugated polymers were designed and synthesized to ext. structure-property relationships with the goal of yielding yellow-to-transmissive switching electrochromes. The polymers are based on repeat units of propylenedioxythiophene (ProDOT) in alternation with a variety of arylenes including 1,4-phenylene (ProDOT-Ph), 2,7-fluorene (ProDOT-Fl), 2,7-carbazole (ProDOT-Cbz), 2,5-dimethoxy-1,4-phenylene (ProDOT-Ph(MeO)2), and 2,7-pyrene (ProDOT-Py). Addnl., a random copolymer contg. ProDOT and two different arylene units was produced: ProDOT-phenylene-ProDOT-dimethoxyphenylene (R-ProDOT-Ph/Ph(MeO)2) and two polymers with a ProDOT dimer in alternation with pyrene and phenylene composed ProDOT2-pyrene (ProDOT2-Py) and ProDOT2-phenylene (ProDOT2-Ph), resp. The polymers were synthesized using Suzuki polycondensation. Examns. of the optoelectronic properties via UV-vis-NIR spectroscopy, differential pulse voltammetry, and spectroelectrochem. show that varying the electron richness of the polymer by utilizing more electron rich arylenes, dimers of ProDOT, or less electron rich arylenes, the oxidn. potential could be decreased or increased, resp., ranging from 270 to 650 mV. Through subtle C-H ortho interactions from the arylene unit, yellow neutral state colors were maintained with transmissive or near-transmissive oxidized states. Colorimetry utilizing L*a*b*, where a*b* values correlate to the chroma or satn. of a color (note: -a* and +a* correspond to green and red and -b* and +b* correspond to blue and yellow, resp.) and L* represents the lightness, was used to show the maintenance of yellow colors in the neutral states. Herein, the yellow polymers had L* values above 84.0, a* values ranging from -11.6 to 24.8, and b* values greater than 47.6. In the oxidized states, the most transmissive forms had L* values above 70.0, a* values ranging from -2.1 to 2.0, and b* values ranging from -6.8 to -0.1. These structure-property relationships grant access to conjugated polymers with high energy absorbance in the visible, while allowing variability in redox potentials, providing a deeper understanding in yielding yellow-to-transmissive electrochromic polymers.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2cXht12gu73N&md5=ac2ff339f14b2bb7494bdf114ca30982
      30. 30
        Cao, K.; Shen, D. E.; Österholm, A. M.; Kerszulis, J. A.; Reynolds, J. R. Tuning Color, Contrast, and Redox Stability in High Gap Cathodically Coloring Electrochromic Polymers. Macromolecules 2016, 49, 8498– 8507,  DOI: 10.1021/acs.macromol.6b01763
        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
        30
        Tuning Color, Contrast, and Redox Stability in High Gap Cathodically Coloring Electrochromic Polymers
        Cao, Kangli; Shen, D. Eric; Osterholm, Anna M.; Kerszulis, Justin A.; Reynolds, John R.
        Macromolecules (Washington, DC, United States) (2016), 49 (22), 8498-8507CODEN: MAMOBX; ISSN:0024-9297. (American Chemical Society)
        The design of high bandgap electrochromic polymers (ECPs) that switch from a high energy absorbing colored state to a near IR absorbing colorless state requires a challenging balance to be struck between achieving large changes in the absorption profile while maintaining sufficiently low oxidn. potentials for use in full-color electrochromic devices. Previous studies on high bandgap ECPs have studied structure-property relationships in dioxythiophenes copolymd. with various arylenes. Here, we expand this understanding by looking more closely at the effect of the dioxythiophene moiety, as well varying the substituents on the arylene moiety. Three ECPs were synthesized to perform this study with repeat units comprised of electron-rich dimethoxyphenylene in alternation with dimers of 3,4-dialkoxy- and 3,4-propylenedioxythiophenes, yielding high-gap polymers that are vibrant yellow or orange in the charge neutral state. Comparing these newly synthesized polymers to a structurally similar set previously reported, we elucidate the subtle steric and electronic effects that govern bandgap and redox properties in dioxythiophene copolymers.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC28XhvVagu7nK&md5=7570a6e1e9c5dca26db72adec9af99cb

        A neutral state yellow to navy polymer electrochrome with pyrene scaffold
        Icli-Ozkut, Merve; Oztas, Zahide; Algi, Fatih; Cihaner, Atilla
        Organic Electronics (2011), 12 (9), 1505-1511CODEN: OERLAU; ISSN:1566-1199. (Elsevier B.V.)
        A new pyrene based sol. polymer, namely poly(3,3-didecyl-6-(1-(3,3-didecyl-3,4-dihydro-2H-thieno[3,4-b][1,4]dioxepin-6-yl)pyren-6-yl)-3,4-dihydro-2H-thieno[3,4-b][1,4]dioxepine), P5, which is synthesized by both chem. and electrochem. methods, is highlighted. The polymer shows both electrochromic and fluorescent properties (the emission of yellow (545 nm) and yellowish green light (524 nm) in solid state and in THF soln., resp.). It is noteworthy that P5 has a specific optical band gap (2.2 eV) to reflect the yellow color in the neutral state. Furthermore, the optical and electrochem. features of the polymer were investigated.

        Oguzhan, E.; Bilgili, H.; Baycan Koyuncu, F.; Ozdemir, E.; Koyuncu, S. A New Processable Donor–Acceptor Polymer Displaying Neutral State Yellow Electrochromism. Polymer 2013, 54, 6283– 6292,  DOI: 10.1016/j.polymer.2013.09.033
