        Estrada, L. A.; Deininger, J. J.; Kamenov, G. D.; Reynolds, J. R. Direct (Hetero)arylation Polymerization: An Effective Route to 3,4-Propylenedioxythiophene-Based Polymers with Low Residual Metal Content. ACS Macro Lett. 2013, 2, 869– 873,  DOI: 10.1021/mz4003886
        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
        72
        Direct (Hetero)arylation Polymerization: An Effective Route to 3,4-Propylenedioxythiophene-Based Polymers with Low Residual Metal Content
        Estrada, Leandro A.; Deininger, James J.; Kamenov, George D.; Reynolds, John R.
        ACS Macro Letters (2013), 2 (10), 869-873CODEN: AMLCCD; ISSN:2161-1653. (American Chemical Society)
        We report the use of direct (hetero)-arylation polymns. (DHAP) as a means of obtaining 3,4-propylenedioxythiophene-based conjugated polymers for use in electrochromics. This method offers a rapid route to achieving polymers in high yields with simplified purifn. procedures and low residual metal content, as detd. by inductive coupled plasma-mass spectrometry (ICP-MS). The studied polymers possess comparable electrochromic properties to those previously reported by our group, implying that their switching ability from a colored to a transmissive state is independent of the residual metallic impurities.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC3sXhsFWksLnK&md5=3e9936cbe01ddf4ac5c9608a592b460c
      73. 73
        Pouliot, J.-R.; Grenier, F.; Blaskovits, J. T.; Beaupré, S.; Leclerc, M. Direct (Hetero)arylation Polymerization: Simplicity for Conjugated Polymer Synthesis. Chem. Rev. 2016, 116, 14225– 14274,  DOI: 10.1021/acs.chemrev.6b00498
        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
        73
        Direct (Hetero)arylation Polymerization: Simplicity for Conjugated Polymer Synthesis
        Pouliot, Jean-Remi; Grenier, Francois; Blaskovits, J. Terence; Beaupre, Serge; Leclerc, Mario
        Chemical Reviews (Washington, DC, United States) (2016), 116 (22), 14225-14274CODEN: CHREAY; ISSN:0009-2665. (American Chemical Society)
        A review. Direct (hetero)arylation polymn. (DHAP) has recently been established as an environmentally benign method for the prepn. of conjugated polymers. This synthetic tool features the formation of C-C bonds between halogenated (hetero)arenes and simple (hetero)arenes with active C-H bonds, thereby circumventing the prepn. of organometallic derivs. and decreasing the overall prodn. cost of conjugated polymers. Since its inception, selectivity and reactivity of DHAP procedures were improved tremendously through the careful scrutiny of polymn. outcomes and the fine-tuning of reaction conditions. A broad range of monomers, from simple arenes to complex functionalized heteroarenes, can now be readily polymd. The successful application of DHAP led to nearly defect-free conjugated polymers possessing comparable, if not slightly better, characteristics than their counterparts prepd. using more classical cross-coupling methods. This comprehensive review describes the mechanisms involved in this process, from exptl. and theor. standpoints, and presents an up-to-date compendium of materials obtained by this mean and exposes its current limitations and challenges.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC28XhslOmu7nI&md5=a77872e56483484e07eb6030052bd598
      74. 74
        Gobalasingham, N. S.; Thompson, B. C. Direct Arylation Polymerization: A Guide to Optimal Conditions for Effective Conjugated Polymers. Prog. Polym. Sci. 2018, 83, 135– 201,  DOI: 10.1016/j.progpolymsci.2018.06.002
        [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
        74
        Direct arylation polymerization: A guide to optimal conditions for effective conjugated polymers
        Gobalasingham, Nemal S.; Thompson, Barry C.
        Progress in Polymer Science (2018), 83 (), 135-201CODEN: PRPSB8; ISSN:0079-6700. (Elsevier Ltd.)
        The rapid increase in the breadth and scope of transformations that involve metal-promoted activation of C-H bonds is fundamentally changing the field of synthetic chem. Direct arylation polymn. is a newly established synthetic protocol for atom economical, effective, and affordable prepn. of conjugated polymers, which continue to be incredibly advantageous as operative materials for a diverse and continually evolving array of applications. This route toward conjugated polymers for high performance materials is particularly appealing because it circumvents the prepn. of organometallic derivs. and the assocd. cryogenic air- and water-free reactions. Although a broad range of monomers are now readily polymerizable, direct arylation polymn. is known to produce defects in the chem. structure, which have a strong impact on the optical, electronic, and thermal properties of conjugated polymers. Fundamental understanding of the underlying considerations when employing different reaction protocols is required to truly enable a broad reaching platform.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC1cXht1SjsbrI&md5=28ce29289b5cd6e7ef6b1ca3c342cddb
      75. 75
        Collier, G. S.; Reynolds, J. R. Exploring the Utility of Buchwald Ligands for C–H Oxidative Direct Arylation Polymerizations. ACS Macro Lett. 2019, 8, 931– 936,  DOI: 10.1021/acsmacrolett.9b00395
        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
        75
        Exploring the Utility of Buchwald Ligands for C-H Oxidative Direct Arylation Polymerizations
        Collier, Graham S.; Reynolds, John R.
        ACS Macro Letters (2019), 8 (8), 931-936CODEN: AMLCCD; ISSN:2161-1653. (American Chemical Society)
        Oxidative C-H/C-H cross-coupling polymns. provide an opportunity to synthesize conjugated polymers with an increased ease of monomer prepn., reduced environmental impact, and increased sustainability. Considering these attributes, it is necessary to expand the diversity of monomers that readily and efficiently participate in this coupling strategy to enable the development of conjugated polymers with a wide range of properties. Herein, the oxidative direct arylation polymn. toolbox is expanded to include 3,4-propylenedioxythiophene being synthesized via C-H/C-H cross-coupling methodologies. In conjunction with these efforts, the utilization of Buchwald ligands in C-H/C-H cross coupling polymns. also is reported, and variations in the ligand structure provide insight into the role ligand choice has on C-H cross-coupling polymns. Specifically, it is detd. that the phosphine functionality affects the rate-detg., concerted metalation-deprotonation step of the catalytic cycle, while bulky iso-Pr substituents on the ligand's lower aryl ring promote reductive elimination. By balancing these steric effects on the ancillary ligands, polymers are synthesized to exhibit mol. wts. above the effective conjugation length, with recovered yields >90%. In addn. to expanding the scope of conjugated polymers accessible via oxidative direct arylation polymn., these results provide the foundational understanding for utilizing Buchwald-type ligands in C-H-activated polymns.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC1MXhtlOju7zJ&md5=d89af15f41c7206f6204ee6f311485b3
      76. 76
        Lo, C. K.; Gautam, B. R.; Selter, P.; Zheng, Z.; Oosterhout, S. D.; Constantinou, I.; Knitsch, R.; Wolfe, R. M. W.; Yi, X.; Brédas, J.-L.; So, F.; Toney, M. F.; Coropceanu, V.; Hansen, M. R.; Gundogdu, K.; Reynolds, J. R. Every Atom Counts: Elucidating the Fundamental Impact of Structural Change in Conjugated Polymers for Organic Photovoltaics. Chem. Mater. 2018, 30, 2995– 3009,  DOI: 10.1021/acs.chemmater.8b00590
        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
        76
        Every Atom Counts: Elucidating the Fundamental Impact of Structural Change in Conjugated Polymers for Organic Photovoltaics
        Lo, Chi Kin; Gautam, Bhoj R.; Selter, Philipp; Zheng, Zilong; Oosterhout, Stefan D.; Constantinou, Iordania; Knitsch, Robert; Wolfe, Rylan M. W.; Yi, Xueping; Bredas, Jean-Luc; So, Franky; Toney, Michael F.; Coropceanu, Veaceslav; Hansen, Michael Ryan; Gundogdu, Kenan; Reynolds, John R.
        Chemistry of Materials (2018), 30 (9), 2995-3009CODEN: CMATEX; ISSN:0897-4756. (American Chemical Society)
        As many conjugated polymer-based org. photovoltaic (OPV) materials provide substantial solar power conversion efficiencies (as high as 13%), it is important to develop a deeper understanding of how the primary repeat unit structures impact device performance. We have varied the group 14 atom (C, Si, Ge) at the center of a bithiophene fused ring to elucidate the impact of a minimal repeat unit structure change on the optical, transport, and morphol. properties, which ultimately control device performance. Careful polymn. and polymer purifn. produced 3 1-atom change donor-acceptor conjugated alternating copolymers with similar mol. wts. and dispersities. DFT calcn., absorption spectroscopy, and high-temp. soln. 1H NMR results indicate that poly(dithienosilole-alt-thienopyrrolodione), P(DTS-TPD), and poly(dithienogermole-alt-thienopyrrolodione), P(DTG-TPD) exhibit different rotational conformations when compared to poly(cyclopentadithiophene-alt-thienopyrrolodione), P(DTC-TPD). Solid-state 1H MASNMR expts. reveal that the greater probability of the anticonformation in P(DTS-TPD) and P(DTG-TPD) prevail in the solid phase. The conformational variation seen in soln. and solid-state NMR in turn affects the polymer stacking and intermol. interaction. Two-dimension 1H-1H DQ-SQ NMR correlation spectra shows arom.-arom. correlations for P(DTS-TPD) and P(DTG-TPD), which however, is absent for P(DTC-TPD). In a thin-film interchain packing study using grazing incidence wide-angle x-ray scattering (GIWAXS), we observe the π-face of the conjugated backbones of P(DTC-TPD) aligned edge-on to the substrate, whereas in contrast the π-faces of P(DTS-TPD) and P(DTG-TPD) align parallel to the surface. These differences in polymer conformations and backbone orientations lead to variations in the OPV performance of blends with the fullerene PC71BM, with the device contg. P(DTC-TPD):PCBM having a lower fill factor and a lower power conversion efficiency. Ultrafast transient absorption spectroscopy shows the P(DTC-TPD):PCBM blend to have a more pronounced triplet formation from bimol. recombination of initially sepd. charges. With a combination of sub-bandgap external quantum efficiency measurements and DFT calcns., we present evidence that the greater charge recombination loss is the result of a lower lying triplet energy level for P(DTC-TPD), leading to a higher rate of recombination and lower OPV device performance. Importantly, this study ties ultimate photovoltaic performance to morphol. features in the active films that are induced from the processing soln. and are a result of minimal 1-atom differences in polymer repeat unit structure.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC1cXnvVWju7o%253D&md5=49b0e216f25a98f9f57125163dd565ce
      77. 77
        Kaake, L.; Dang, X.-D.; Leong, W. L.; Zhang, Y.; Heeger, A.; Nguyen, T.-Q. Effects of Impurities on Operational Mechanism of Organic Bulk Heterojunction Solar Cells. Adv. Mater. 2013, 25, 1706– 1712,  DOI: 10.1002/adma.201203786
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        77
        Effects of Impurities on Operational Mechanism of Organic Bulk Heterojunction Solar Cells
        Kaake, Loren; Dang, Xuan-Dung; Leong, Wei Lin; Zhang, Yuan; Heeger, Alan; Nguyen, Thuc-Quyen
        Advanced Materials (Weinheim, Germany) (2013), 25 (12), 1706-1712CODEN: ADVMEW; ISSN:0935-9648. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
        The effect is investigated of 14,14,8,8-teracyanoquinodimethane (TCNQ) and [6,6]phenyl-C84-butyric acid Me ester (PC84BM) on the performance of PCDTBT:PC60BM devices to gain insight into whether differing impurity shapes may lead to different loss mechanisms. Light intensity dependent solar cell characteristics, photoconductive at. force microscopy, charge carrier mobility using single-carrier diodes, and transient absorption spectroscopy were performed to probe the loss mechanism. Although solar cell performance is decreased upon the addn. of TCNQ, a qual. different loss mechanism is found for TCNQ and PC84BM.

        Diemer, P. J.; Hayes, J.; Welchman, E.; Hallani, R.; Pookpanratana, S. J.; Hacker, C. A.; Richter, C. A.; Anthony, J. E.; Thonhauser, T.; Jurchescu, O. D.       79. 79
        Curtin, I. J.; Blaylock, D. W.; Holmes, R. J. Role of Impurities in Determining the Exciton Diffusion Length in Organic Semiconductors. Appl. Phys. Lett. 2016, 108, 163301,  DOI: 10.1063/1.4945688
        [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
        79
        Role of impurities in determining the exciton diffusion length in organic semiconductors
        Curtin, Ian J.; Blaylock, D. Wayne; Holmes, Russell J.
        Applied Physics Letters (2016), 108 (16), 163301/1-163301/4CODEN: APPLAB; ISSN:0003-6951. (American Institute of Physics)
        The design and performance of org. photovoltaic cells is dictated, in part, by the magnitude of the exciton diffusion length (LD). Despite the importance of this parameter, there have been few investigations connecting LD and materials purity. Here, we investigate LD for the org. small mol. N,N'-bis(naphthalen-1-yl)-N,N'-bis(phenyl)-benzidine as native impurities are systematically removed from the material. Thin films deposited from the as-synthesized material yield a value for LD, as measured by photoluminescence quenching, of (3.9 ± 0.5) nm with a corresponding photoluminescence efficiency (ηPL) of (25 ± 1)% and thin film purity of (97.1 ± 1.2)%, measured by high performance liq. chromatog. After purifn. by thermal gradient sublimation, the value of LD is increased to (4.7 ± 0.5) nm with a corresponding ηPL of (33 ± 1)% and purity of (98.3 ± 0.8)%. Interestingly, a similar behavior is also obsd. as a function of the deposition boat temp. Films deposited from the purified material at a high temp. give LD = (5.3 ± 0.8) nm with ηPL = (37 ± 1)% for films with a purity of (99.0 ± 0.3)% purity. Using a model of diffusion by Forster energy transfer, the variation of LD with purity is predicted as a function of ηPL and is in good agreement with measurements. The removal of impurities acts to decrease the non-radiative exciton decay rate and increase the radiative decay rate, leading to increases in both the diffusivity and exciton lifetime. The results of this work highlight the role of impurities in detg. LD, while also providing insight into the degree of materials purifn. necessary to achieve optimized exciton transport. (c) 2016 American Institute of Physics.
        >> More from SciFinder ®

        Bracher, C.; Yi, H.; Scarratt, N. W.; Masters, R.; Pearson, A. J.; Rodenburg, C.; Iraqi, A.; Lidzey, D. G. The Effect of Residual Palladium Catalyst on the Performance and Stability of PCDTBT:PC70BM Organic Solar Cells. Org. Electron. 2015, 27, 266– 273,  DOI: 10.1016/j.orgel.2015.10.001
        [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
        80
        The effect of residual palladium catalyst on the performance and stability of PCDTBT:PC70BM organic solar cells
        Bracher, Christopher; Yi, Hunan; Scarratt, Nicholas W.; Masters, Robert; Pearson, Andrew J.; Rodenburg, Cornelia; Iraqi, Ahmed; Lidzey, David G.
        Organic Electronics (2015), 27 (), 266-273CODEN: OERLAU; ISSN:1566-1199. (Elsevier B.V.)
        Palladium (Pd) is commonly used as a catalyst in the polymn. of conjugated polymers such as poly[N-9'-heptadecanyl-2,7-carbozole-alt-5,5-(4',7'-di-2-thenyl-2',1',3'-benzothiadiazole)] (PCDTBT). Here we explore the effect of residual catalyst on the performance of org. photovoltaic devices (OPVs) based on a PCDTBT:fullerene thin-film blend. We find that as the relative concn. of Pd increases, the power conversion efficiency of the PV is reduced, dropping from 4.55% to 2.42% as the Pd concn. was increased to 2570 ppm (relative to that of the PCDTBT). This redn. in efficiency resulted primarily from a redn. in PV fill factor and shunt-resistance, indicating the presence of current-shunts within the device. Using optical microscopy, laser beam induced current mapping and SEM, we are able to demonstrate that such current shunts are assocd. with micron-sized aggregates of Pd-contg. nanoparticles. We show that the presence of high concns. of Pd within a PCDTBT OPV contribute to a larger drop in efficiency during the initial 'burn-in' period.

        Metal Residues in Semiconducting Polymers: Impact on the Performance of Organic Electronic Devices
        Usluer, Ozlem; Abbas, Mamatimin; Wantz, Guillaume; Vignau, Laurence; Hirsch, Lionel; Grana, Eftychia; Brochon, Cyril; Cloutet, Eric; Hadziioannou, Georges
        ACS Macro Letters (2014), 3 (11), 1134-1138CODEN: AMLCCD; ISSN:2161-1653. (American Chemical Society)
        The effect of impurities on the optoelectronic and charge transport properties of semiconducting polymers was studied through the performance of org. photovoltaics (OPVs) and org. field effect transistors (OFETs), resp. A model representative semiconducting polymer, i.e., poly(3-hexylthiophene) (P3HT), was synthesized and purified using different methods such as pptn., metals' complexation, and Soxhlet extn. After the purifn. processes, each fraction was analyzed to det. its compn. in metals (impurities) by various techniques. OFETs and OPVs fabricated from these purified polymer fractions show different charge carrier properties and photovoltaic behaviors. The purest fraction which was obtained after Soxhlet extn. complemented by metals' complexation with the help of ethylenediamine and 15-crown-5 ether showed the best performance in both OPVs and OFETs.

        Koch, F. P. V.; Rivnay, J.; Foster, S.; Müller, C.; Downing, J. M.; Buchaca-Domingo, E.; Westacott, P.; Yu, L.; Yuan, M.; Baklar, M.; Fei, Z.; Luscombe, C.; McLachlan, M. Sci. 2013, 38, 1978– 1989,  DOI: 10.1016/j.progpolymsci.2013.07.009

        82
        The impact of molecular weight on microstructure and charge transport in semicrystalline polymer semiconductors - poly(3-hexylthiophene), a model study
        Koch, Felix Peter Vinzenz; Rivnay, Jonathan; Foster, Sam; Muller, Christian; Downing, Jonathan M.; Buchaca-Domingo, Ester; Westacott, Paul; Yu, Liyang; Yuan, Mingjian; Baklar, Mohammed; Fei, Zhuping; Luscombe, Christine; McLachlan, Martyn A.; Heeney, Martin; Rumbles, Garry; Silva, Carlos; Salleo, Alberto; Nelson, Jenny; Smith, Paul; Stingelin, Natalie
        Progress in Polymer Science (2013), 38 (12), 1978-1989CODEN: PRPSB8; ISSN:0079-6700. (Elsevier Ltd.)
        A review. Electronic properties of org. semiconductors are often critically dependent upon their ability to order from the mol. level to the macro-scale, as is true for many other materials attributes of macromol. matter such as mech. characteristics. Therefore, understanding of the mol. assembly process and the resulting solid-state short- and long-range order is crit. to further advance the field of org. electronics. Here, we will discuss the structure development as a function of mol. wt. in thin films of a model conjugated polymer, poly(3-hexylthiophene) (P3HT), when processed from soln. and the melt. While focus is on the microstructural manipulation and characterization, we also treat the influence of mol. arrangement and order on electronic processes such as charge transport and show, based on classical polymer science arguments, how accounting for the structural complexity of polymers can provide a basis for establishing relevant processing/structure/property-interrelationships to explain some of their electronic features. Such relationships can assist with the design of new materials and definition of processing protocols that account for the mol. length, chain rigidity and propensity to order of a given system.

        Heimel, G. The Optical Signature of Charges in Conjugated Polymers. ACS Cent. Sci. 2016, 2, 309– 315,  DOI: 10.1021/acscentsci.6b00073
        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
        85
        The Optical Signature of Charges in Conjugated Polymers
        Heimel, Georg
        ACS Central Science (2016), 2 (5), 309-315CODEN: ACSCII; ISSN:2374-7951. (American Chemical Society)
        Elec. charge flowing through org. semiconductors drives many of today's mobile phone displays and television screens, suggesting an internally consistent model of charge-carrier properties in these materials to have manifested. In conjugated polymers, charges give rise to addnl. absorption of light at wavelengths longer than those absorbed by the elec. neutral species. These characteristic absorption bands are universally being related to the emergence of localized energy levels shifted into the forbidden gap of org. semiconductors due to local relaxation of the mol. geometry. The traditional view on these energy levels and their occupation is incompatible with expected changes in electron removal and addn. energies upon charging mols. Local Coulomb repulsion, as captured by nonempirically optimized electronic-structure calcns., restores compatibility and suggests a different origin of the charge-induced optical transitions. These results challenge a widely accepted and long-established picture, but an improved understanding of charge carriers in mol. materials promises a more targeted development of org. and hybrid org./inorg. (opto-)electronic devices.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC28XmvVyhtr8%253D&md5=a72e893c7a4a068769ca68b6256bdd5d

The Effects of Crystallinity on Charge Transport and the Structure of Sequentially Processed F4TCNQ-Doped Conjugated Polymer Films. Adv. Funct. Mater. 2017, 27, 1702654,  DOI: 10.1002/adfm.201702654

      87. 87
        Leclerc, M.; Fréchette, M.; Bergeron, J.-Y.; Ranger, M.; Lévesque, I.; Faïd, K. Chromic Phenomena in Neutral Polythiophene Derivatives. Macromol. Chem. Phys. 1996, 197, 2077– 2087,  DOI: 10.1002/macp.1996.021970701
        [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
        87
        Chromic phenomena in neutral polythiophene derivatives
        Leclerc, Mario; Frechette, Martin; Bergeron, Jean Yves; Ranger, Maxime; Levesque, Isabelle; Faid, Karim
        Macromolecular Chemistry and Physics (1996), 197 (7), 2077-2087CODEN: MCHPES; ISSN:1022-1352. (Huethig & Wepf)
        Thermochromic phenomena in various regioregular and non-regioregular polythiophene derivs. were investigated both in the solid state and in soln. These studies have revealed the existence of 2 different types of thermochromic phenomena which are correlated to the substitution pattern of the polymers. Formation of delocalized conformational defects (twistons) was obsd. in regioregular polythiophene derivs. but do not occur in non-regioregular polythiophenes. For the latter polymers, only localized conformational defects can be created along the polymer backbone leading to a monotonic blue shift of the absorption max. upon heating. All these optical features are driven by order-disorder transitions of the side-chains, side-chain disordering increasing their steric hindrance and/or disrupting short-range ordered assemblies, which then force the thiophene backbone to adopt a nonplanar conformation. Non-covalent interactions between alkali metal ions and regioregular ether-substituted polythiophenes can modify the side-chain organization and can lead to interesting ionochromic effects. Chromic phenomena can be induced via a large range of external stimuli which should lead to the development of novel affinity-chromic and photochromic materials.
        >> More from SciFinder ®

        Hassab, S.; Shen, D. E.; Österholm, A. M.; Da Rocha, M.; Song, G.; Alesanco, Y.; Viñuales, A.; Rougier, A.; Reynolds, J. R.; Padilla, J. A New Standard Method to Calculate Electrochromic Switching Time. Sol. Energy Mater. Sol. Cells 2018, 185, 54– 60,  DOI: 10.1016/j.solmat.2018.04.031

        A new standard method to calculate electrochromic switching time
        Hassab, Sofiane; Shen, D. Eric; Osterholm, Anna M.; Da Rocha, Mathias; Song, Giljoo; Alesanco, Yolanda; Vinuales, Ana; Rougier, Aline; Reynolds, John R.; Padilla, Javier
        Solar Energy Materials & Solar Cells (2018), 185 (), 54-60CODEN: SEMCEQ; ISSN:0927-0248. (Elsevier B.V.)
        The switching time is one of the key parameters used to assess the performance of an electrochromic material or device. In spite of its importance, there is currently no std. for how this parameter is defined, and as a result, it is difficult to compare switching time data between different research groups, and to quantify and assess reported improvements. We propose a std. method for reporting electrochromic switching times, based on straightforward exptl. fittings resulting in an anal. expression that can directly correlate obtainable optical contrast values with their corresponding switching times. This anal. expression makes it possible to unambiguously define the performance of an electrochromic material or device using two parameters: a full-switch contrast and a time const.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC1cXpsVGisrY%253D&md5=37041a9a190e63d4f94c26e1717a7b0f
      90. 90
        Brown, P. J.; Thomas, D. S.; Köhler, A.; Wilson, J. S.; Kim, J.-S.; Ramsdale, C. M.; Sirringhaus, H.; Friend, R. H. Effect of Interchain Interactions on the Absorption and Emission of Poly(3-hexylthiophene). Phys. Rev. B: Condens. Matter Mater. Phys. 2003, 67, 064203,  DOI: 10.1103/PhysRevB.67.064203
        [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
        90
        Effect of interchain interactions on the absorption and emission of poly(3-hexyl-thiophene)
        Brown, Peter J.; Thomas, D. Steve; Kohler, Anna; Wilson, Joanne S.; Kim, Ji-Seon; Ramsdale, Catherine M.; Sirringhaus, Henning; Friend, Richard H.
        Physical Review B: Condensed Matter and Materials Physics (2003), 67 (6), 064203/1-064203/16CODEN: PRBMDO; ISSN:0163-1829. (American Physical Society)
        The absorption spectrum of polythiophene and its deriv. poly(3-hexyl-thiophene) (P3HT) is usually described in terms of an intrachain exciton coupled to a single phonon mode. We show that this model is too simplistic for highly ordered, regio-regular P3HT and that, analogous to the case of charged polarons in this material, interchain interactions must be taken into account to correctly describe the absorption spectrum. We show that the lowest energy feature in the π-π* region of the absorption spectrum is assocd. with an interchain absorption, the intensity of which is correlated with the degree of order in the polymer. Correspondingly, we show that the emission from P3HT also exhibits contributions from both interchain and intrachain states, in a manner similar to that recently shown for poly(phenylenevinylene). Having reinterpreted the phys. origin of the features in the absorption and emission spectra of P3HT, we then model these spectra and show how they evolve as the degree of order in the polymer is changed by varying several phys. parameters including temp. and regio regularity of the polymer.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD3sXitV2rt78%253D&md5=9026111e649a817f15b62cc5f678f333
      91. 91
        Österholm, A. M.; Ponder, J. F.; De Keersmaecker, M.; Shen, D. E.; Reynolds, J. R. Disentangling Redox Properties and Capacitance in Solution-Processed Conjugated Polymers. Chem. Mater. 2019, 31, 2971– 2982,  DOI: 10.1021/acs.chemmater.9b00528
        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
        91
        Disentangling Redox Properties and Capacitance in Solution-Processed Conjugated Polymers
        Osterholm, Anna M.; Ponder, James F.; De Keersmaecker, Michel; Shen, D. Eric; Reynolds, John R.
        Chemistry of Materials (2019), 31 (8), 2971-2982CODEN: CMATEX; ISSN:0897-4756. (American Chemical Society)
        The unique ability of combined ionic and electronic transport in conjugated, semiconducting polymers has resulted in the emergence of a variety of redox-based technologies ranging from energy storage and conversion, to bioelectronics, to on-demand color control. Although conjugated polymers have been extensively studied for decades, the recent revival of org. bioelectronics, in particular, has demonstrated that there needs to be a better understanding of the interplay between mixed ion and electron transport and the underlying film morphol. Many of the conjugated polymers that are effectively doped electrochem. and that exhibit a combination of high capacitance, fast and reversible redox switching, and exceptional stability lack long-range order making it more challenging to evaluate how the morphol. evolves as a function of oxidn. state. Here, we demonstrate how readily accessible electrochem. and spectroscopic techniques can offer a great deal of insight into ion and electron transport in redox-active conjugated polymers regardless of their degree of order. Furthermore, we show how numerous redox properties, including onset of oxidn., capacitance, and conductance profile, of five dioxythiophene-based copolymers can be manipulated by the size and polarity of the functional groups that are incorporated to provide soln. processability.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC1MXmsVagsr0%253D&md5=ef1b69e3039d0a58eb15553c85d7a7aa
